awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Cyber Security Education Using POGIL
awd_abstract_narration:
Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) has been proven effective in improving discipline-based student learning and professional skills such as teamwork, communication, management, information processing, and critical thinking. This project develops POGIL materials for fifteen cybersecurity topic areas of cryptography, access control, network security, risk management, web security, and secure coding. This project also evaluates the developed POGIL materials and teaching methods in different courses at three universities with the goal of investigating the following research question: Is using the POGIL method more effective to learn cybersecurity than traditional/lecture-based teaching methods in terms of learning outcomes, learning experience, attitudes and motivation? This project also builds the national capacity in cybersecurity education and disseminates project results through holding two in-conference faculty workshops and one summer faculty workshop as faculty professional development in  cybersecurity.  This project is implemented through the collaboration of PIs from North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University, the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, and Old Dominion University.

The developed POGIL materials will contribute to the effective pedagogy resources for cybersecurity education. The study of the effectiveness of the POGIL instructional method for cybersecurity education will contribute to the research knowledge on effective teaching methods for cybersecurity. The developed POGIL materials can be adopted by multiple disciplines such as computer science, information technology and business, and will be made available to a broader audience through conference presentations, publication in appropriate journals, and through the project's web site.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this collaborative project is to address cybersecurity education challenges and increase university and college cybersecurity education capacity. The project team developed, implemented, evaluated, and disseminated cybersecurity teaching materials based on Guided Inquiry and Collaborative Learning. The team developed and assessed teaching materials for SQL injection, discretionary access control, mandatory access control, symmetric cryptography, public-key cryptography, key management, and virtual private databases. These materials were offered in four courses: Databases and Security, Advanced Database and Security, Biometrics and Cryptography, and Advanced Biometrics and Cryptography.  From 2017 to 2021, these materials were taught to hundreds of students in four courses: Databases and Security, Advanced Database and Security, Biometrics and Cryptography, and Advanced Biometrics and Cryptography. Based on the comparison of the pre- and post-surveys, students reported positive learning experiences on teamwork, communications, attitude and motivation, and learning gains on cyber security concepts and skills. Faculty workshops, conference presentations, and websites were used to disseminate the developed teaching materials and pedagogy. The collaboration of the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, North Carolina A&T State University, and Old Dominion University was strengthened through this project. This project provided undergraduate and graduate researchers with cybersecurity research training. Overall, this project contributed to the development of professionals and workforce in cybersecurity by creating transferable teaching materials that improve student learning experience of domain knowledge and soft skills training.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2021
Modified by: Hong Qin
